content.title: Femoral Access Site Complications
content.definition: Femoral access site complications are adverse events occurring at or related to the common femoral artery puncture site during diagnostic or therapeutic vascular and cardiac procedures, including hematoma, pseudoaneurysm, arteriovenous fistula, thrombosis, and retroperitoneal hemorrhage.

hematoma.severe: May require surgical evacuation if expanding or compromising limb

arteriovenous_fistula.mechanism: Through-and-through puncture of artery and vein
arteriovenous_fistula.diagnosis: Continuous bruit, arterialized vein on duplex

treatment.surgical_repair: Alternative if anatomy not suitable for stent

retroperitoneal_hemorrhage.mechanism: High puncture (above inguinal ligament) or posterior wall perforation
treatment: Covered stent or surgical repair if ongoing

thrombosis.mechanism: Dissection, prolonged compression, large sheath in small artery

access_technique.proper_level: Over common femoral artery (not SFA, not external iliac)

closure_devices.outcomes: May reduce time to hemostasis, not clearly reduce complications

prevention.anticoagulation_management: Hold anticoagulation for sheath removal when possible

learning_objectives: List common femoral access site complications and their incidence
Describe management algorithm for femoral pseudoaneurysm

clinical_pearls: High puncture (above inguinal ligament) risks retroperitoneal hemorrhage
Unexplained hypotension after femoral access = think retroperitoneal bleed
Thrombin injection is first-line for femoral pseudoaneurysm >2cm
